title: Migraine with Aura
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of migraine with typical aura (visual, sensory, language) and hemiplegic migraine. Focuses on outpatient management with acute care considerations. Covers differentiation from TIA/stroke, contraceptive counseling, and preventive therapy. Excludes migraine with brainstem aura (separate protocol) and retinal migraine.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out anemia, infection; baseline before treatment
Electrolyte abnormalities; renal function for medication dosing
Hypoglycemia can mimic aura; hyperglycemia raises stroke risk
Coagulation screen if stroke consideration; before LP

Extended Workup.rationale: Rule out GCA if age >50 with new visual symptoms
Thyroid dysfunction can trigger headache/aura-like symptoms
Deficiency linked to migraine with aura specifically
Elevated levels associated with migraine with aura and stroke
Deficiency can elevate homocysteine; sensory symptoms
Deficiency associated with increased migraine frequency

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Thrombophilia workup if young stroke or recurrent prolonged aura
Hereditary thrombophilia if recurrent aura or stroke-like events
Rule out meningitis, SAH if atypical presentation

Essential/First-line.timing: First presentation with aura; rule out stroke/structural lesion
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; no acute infarct; no WMH concerning for vasculopathy

Essential/First-line.timing: Acute presentation if MRI unavailable; rule out hemorrhage
First aura or prolonged aura to assess intracranial vessels

Extended.timing: Atypical features; persistent deficits; concern for mass
Suspected cervical dissection (neck pain, Horner syndrome)
Acute vascular imaging if MRI unavailable
Evaluate for PFO if recurrent aura or cryptogenic stroke history
Extended.target: No PFO; if present, assess shunt size

Rare/Specialized.timing: Detailed cardiac source evaluation if TTE positive or high suspicion
Prolonged aura to differentiate migrainous infarct from stroke
PFO screening; noninvasive alternative to TTE bubble
Aura with altered consciousness; differentiate from seizure

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line acute migraine with aura in ED

dosing.instructions: 30 mg IV (15 mg if >65y, renal impairment, or <50 kg); max 5 days NSAIDs

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Renal impairment (CrCl <30); active GI bleed; aspirin/NSAID allergy; third trimester

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV over 15 min; pretreat with diphenhydramine 25 mg IV to prevent akathisia

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Parkinson's disease; tardive dyskinesia history; bowel obstruction; pheochromocytoma

Acute/Emergent.indication: Dopamine antagonist for acute migraine with prominent nausea

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV slowly over 2 min; pretreat with diphenhydramine 25 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: QT prolongation (QTc >500ms); Parkinson's disease; neuroleptic malignant syndrome history

Acute/Emergent.indication: Prevent akathisia from dopamine antagonists; sedation

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV given concurrently with dopamine antagonist

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; severe prostatic hypertrophy

Acute/Emergent.indication: Migraine with aura - particularly effective; refractory migraine

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV in 50 mL NS over 20-30 min; may repeat x1 after 2 hr

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Heart block; severe hypermagnesemia; myasthenia gravis; severe renal impairment
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP, HR during infusion; flushing is common and benign

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute migraine with TYPICAL aura (visual, sensory, language) - SAFE

dosing.instructions: 6 mg SC (may repeat after 1 hr, max 12 mg/24hr) OR 50-100 mg PO (may repeat after 2 hr, max 200 mg/24hr); take AFTER aura resolves or at headache onset

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: **HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE (motor aura)**; uncontrolled HTN; CAD; prior stroke/TIA; MAOIs within 14 days; ergots within 24 hr
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Chest tightness (triptan sensation vs cardiac); assess cardiovascular risk

Acute/Emergent.indication: Status migrainosus with aura; refractory to first-line

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg IV over 5-10 min; may repeat 500 mg in 8 hr

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hepatic disease; pregnancy (teratogenic); urea cycle disorders; pancreatitis history
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: LFTs; ammonia if altered mental status

Acute/Emergent.indication: Prevent headache recurrence after acute treatment

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV x1 at time of discharge or admission; single dose

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Acute typical migraine with aura; fast onset

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg PO (use 5 mg if on propranolol); may repeat after 2 hr; max 30 mg/24hr

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: **HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE (motor aura)**; uncontrolled HTN; CAD; prior stroke/TIA; MAOIs within 14 days; ergots within 24 hr; use 5 mg max if on propranolol

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Acute typical migraine with aura; good for recurrence

dosing.instructions: 40 mg PO; may repeat 40 mg after 2 hr if partial response; max 80 mg/24hr

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: **HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE (motor aura)**; uncontrolled HTN; CAD; prior stroke/TIA; MAOIs within 14 days; ergots within 24 hr; potent CYP3A4 inhibitors (ketoconazole, clarithromycin)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Migraine with aura; longer duration; menstrual migraine

dosing.instructions: 2.5 mg PO; may repeat after 4 hr; max 5 mg/24hr; slower onset but longer lasting

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: **HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE (motor aura)**; uncontrolled HTN; CAD; prior stroke/TIA; MAOIs within 14 days; ergots within 24 hr; moderate-severe renal/hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: CGRP antagonist; use if triptan contraindicated or cardiovascular risk

dosing.instructions: 50-100 mg PO; may repeat after 2 hr; max 200 mg/24hr

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors; severe hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: CGRP antagonist; can use for acute and prevention

dosing.instructions: 75 mg ODT at onset; max 75 mg/24hr for acute; also approved 75 mg every other day for prevention

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers; severe hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: 5-HT1F agonist; safe in cardiovascular disease; ditan class

dosing.instructions: 50-200 mg PO x1; max 200 mg/24hr; DO NOT DRIVE for 8 hours after dose

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent alcohol; CYP3A4 substrates with narrow TI
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: CNS depression; dizziness; NO driving for 8 hr

dosing.instructions: 400-800 mg PO at onset; max 2400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; active GI bleed; aspirin/NSAID allergy; third trimester
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: GI symptoms; renal function if prolonged use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Mild-moderate aura migraine; menstrual migraine prevention

dosing.instructions: 550 mg PO at onset; may add 275 mg in 12 hr; max 1375 mg day 1, then 1100 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; active GI bleed; aspirin/NSAID allergy

dosing.instructions: 2 tablets (250/250/65 mg each) at onset; max 2 doses/24hr

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Aspirin allergy; hepatic impairment; avoid if using other acetaminophen sources

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV or 8 mg PO/ODT; may repeat q8h as needed

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if multiple doses or baseline prolongation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory migraine; status migrainosus; **NOT for hemiplegic**

dosing.instructions: IV: 0.5-1 mg q8h for up to 3 days (pretreat with antiemetic); SC: 1 mg, may repeat in 1 hr; Nasal: 1 spray each nostril, repeat in 15 min

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy; CAD; uncontrolled HTN; peripheral vascular disease; **HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE**; triptan use within 24hr; severe hepatic/renal impairment
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP; nausea; chest pain; continuous cardiac monitoring for IV

dosing.instructions: Inject bupivacaine 0.5% 2-3 mL + triamcinolone 40 mg at greater occipital nerve bilaterally; may add lesser occipital, supraorbital

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Local anesthetic allergy; infection at injection site; anticoagulation (relative)

dosing.instructions: 0.1-0.3 mg/kg/hr continuous infusion for 24-48 hr; subanesthetic dosing only

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN; psychosis history; elevated ICP; pregnancy
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Dissociation; BP; HR; requires continuous cardiac monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Hemiplegic migraine acute (if severe); status migrainosus

dosing.instructions: 5 mg IV over 2-3 min; may repeat in 30 min (max 20 mg)

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Heart block (2nd/3rd degree); severe LV dysfunction; hypotension
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Continuous ECG; BP; for hemiplegic migraine when triptans contraindicated

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute migraine with aura; rapid onset option

dosing.instructions: 4% lidocaine 0.5 mL per nostril directed at sphenopalatine fossa; may repeat x1 in 15 min

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Local numbness; cardiac arrhythmia (rare with low dose)

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: First-line supplement for migraine with aura prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 400 mg daily; may increase to 400 mg BID; take with food to reduce GI upset

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Diarrhea; check Mg level if symptomatic or renal disease

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: First-line oral prevention; reduces aura frequency; weight loss

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg qHS; increase by 25 mg/wk; target 50-100 mg BID

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Cognitive effects; paresthesias; weight; serum bicarbonate; kidney stones

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: First-line prevention; comorbid HTN, anxiety, tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 40 mg BID or 80 mg LA daily; titrate q2wk; target 80-240 mg/day

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: Asthma; COPD with bronchospasm; bradycardia <50; 2nd/3rd degree heart block; decompensated HF
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: HR (goal >50); BP; fatigue; depression; exercise intolerance

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Prevention with comorbid insomnia, depression, tension-type headache

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg q1-2wk; target 25-75 mg qHS

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.pretreatment: ECG if >50 y/o or cardiac history
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: Cardiac conduction disease; recent MI; glaucoma; urinary retention; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Sedation; weight; dry mouth; ECG if dose >100 mg or cardiac history

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily; increase by 37.5-75 mg q1wk; target 75-150 mg daily

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN; MAOIs within 14 days; abrupt discontinuation risk
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: BP at doses >150 mg; serotonin syndrome signs; taper to discontinue

dosing.instructions: Start 8 mg daily; may increase to 16 mg daily after 4 wk

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Prevention with comorbid bipolar or epilepsy

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID or 500 mg ER daily; titrate to 500-1000 mg/day

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: **Pregnancy (teratogenic - neural tube defects)**; hepatic disease; urea cycle disorders; pancreatitis history
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: LFTs q6mo; weight; hair loss; tremor; CBC

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Supplement for prevention; well-tolerated; may reduce aura

dosing.instructions: 400 mg daily
100-300 mg daily

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: CGRP mAb; failed 2+ oral preventives or intolerance

dosing.instructions: 70 mg SC monthly; may increase to 140 mg monthly after 3 months if suboptimal response

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Constipation (can be severe - may need laxatives); injection site reactions; HTN monitoring

dosing.instructions: 225 mg SC monthly OR 675 mg SC quarterly (three 225 mg injections)
240 mg SC loading dose (2 x 120 mg injections), then 120 mg SC monthly

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Chronic migraine with aura (≥15 days/month); failed oral preventives

dosing.instructions: 155-195 units across 31-39 injection sites per PREEMPT protocol; repeat q12 weeks; effect may take 2-3 cycles

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: Infection at injection sites; myasthenia gravis; neuromuscular disorder
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Neck weakness; ptosis; antibody formation if loss of effect

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Calcium channel blocker for prevention; especially hemiplegic migraine

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS; may increase to 10 mg qHS; especially useful for hemiplegic migraine (not available in US)

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: Weight gain; depression; parkinsonism with prolonged use

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: May reduce aura frequency specifically; hemiplegic migraine

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25 mg q2wk to 50-100 mg BID; SLOW titration to prevent rash

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: History of lamotrigine-related rash; interacting drugs (valproate halves dose)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.monitoring: **RASH (stop immediately if rash develops - SJS risk)**; monitor closely during titration

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.indication: Hemiplegic migraine prevention; familial hemiplegic migraine

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; may increase to 500 mg BID

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies (.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe hepatic/renal disease; hypokalemia; acidosis

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Headache specialist referral for aura characterization, preventive optimization, and differentiation from other neurological conditions
OB/GYN consultation for contraceptive counseling - **estrogen-containing contraceptives contraindicated** in migraine with aura due to elevated ischemic stroke risk
Cardiology referral if TTE shows PFO for discussion of closure in select cases (recurrent cryptogenic stroke or debilitating aura despite medical therapy)
Genetics consultation if hemiplegic migraine suspected for CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A testing and family counseling
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component and trigger point management
Psychology/Behavioral medicine for CBT addressing aura anxiety, attack anticipation, and comorbid mood disorders
Ophthalmology if visual aura atypical or concern for retinal pathology
Sleep medicine if sleep disorder contributing to migraine frequency (OSA, insomnia)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new/different headache, "worst headache of life," or thunderclap onset which may indicate subarachnoid hemorrhage
Return immediately if aura persists >60 minutes or if new weakness on one side of body develops (need to rule out stroke)
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate CNS infection
**AVOID estrogen-containing contraceptives** (combined birth control pills, patch, ring) - use progestin-only methods (mini-pill, Depo-Provera, Mirena IUD, Nexplanon) or non-hormonal methods
Triptans ARE safe for your typical visual/sensory aura - take at headache onset or when aura ends; do NOT take if you experience weakness (motor aura)
Maintain headache/aura diary tracking aura type, duration, triggers, and medication use to guide treatment optimization
Limit acute medication use to ≤10 days/month to prevent medication overuse headache which worsens both headache and aura
Learn your personal aura warning signs and take acute medication promptly when headache begins
Do not drive or operate machinery during visual or motor aura as vision and coordination may be impaired

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime) as sleep changes are a major aura trigger
Avoid known aura triggers (bright/flashing lights, high altitude, significant sleep deprivation, extreme stress)
Regular aerobic exercise (30 min moderate activity 5x/week) reduces migraine frequency; avoid if currently in aura
Magnesium-rich diet (leafy greens, nuts, whole grains) or supplementation as magnesium specifically helps aura
Stress management techniques (mindfulness, biofeedback, relaxation training) as stress is a major trigger
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger attacks
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk, particularly important given aura-associated stroke risk
Caffeine moderation (≤200 mg/day) and consistent daily intake to avoid withdrawal triggers
Blood pressure control (target <130/80) given elevated vascular risk with aura
Avoid high altitude or rapid altitude changes if altitude is a known aura trigger

differential.features: Sudden onset (maximal at onset vs gradual aura spread); negative symptoms (vision loss vs positive scintillations); vascular risk factors; older age; duration usually <1 hr
differential.tests: MRI DWI (no restriction in aura); MRA/CTA (no vessel occlusion); aura has visual "march"

differential.features: Fixed deficit; sudden onset; vascular territory distribution; risk factors
differential.tests: MRI DWI (shows restriction); CT may be normal early

differential.features: Aura includes brainstem symptoms (vertigo, tinnitus, decreased hearing, diplopia, ataxia, dysarthria, decreased LOC)
differential.tests: Clinical criteria; MRI to exclude posterior fossa lesion

differential.features: Monocular visual symptoms (vs binocular in typical aura); complete vision loss in one eye
differential.tests: Ophthalmology exam; cover/uncover test during symptoms

differential.features: Shorter duration (seconds to minutes); positive phenomena; may have automatisms; post-ictal confusion
differential.tests: EEG may show epileptiform activity; MRI for structural lesion

differential.features: Anterograde amnesia; repetitive questioning; no visual or motor symptoms; resolves <24 hr
differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis; MRI may show hippocampal DWI changes

differential.features: Age >50; scalp tenderness; jaw claudication; visual loss (not scintillations); elevated ESR/CRP
Neck pain; Horner syndrome; pulsatile tinnitus; stroke symptoms
Migraine with aura often first symptom; subcortical strokes; family history; cognitive decline
differential.tests: MRI shows characteristic WMH (anterior temporal, external capsule); NOTCH3 mutation

differential.features: Stroke-like episodes not following vascular territory; seizures; elevated lactate; short stature
differential.tests: MRI (non-vascular stroke pattern); genetic testing; muscle biopsy

evidence.recommendation: Migraine with aura increases ischemic stroke risk, especially in women using combined oral contraceptives
ACOG: Combined hormonal contraceptives contraindicated in migraine with aura
Triptans safe and effective in migraine with typical aura
Triptans contraindicated in hemiplegic migraine (expert consensus)
Magnesium particularly effective for migraine with aura prevention
Lamotrigine may reduce aura frequency specifically
CGRP monoclonal antibodies effective for prevention
Gepants safe in patients with cardiovascular contraindications to triptans
Lasmiditan (ditan) does not have cardiovascular contraindications
IV magnesium effective for acute migraine with aura
Aura duration >60 minutes warrants stroke evaluation
PFO closure may benefit select patients with migraine with aura
Acetazolamide effective for familial hemiplegic migraine
Verapamil may be used acutely in hemiplegic migraine
Exercise as effective as topiramate for migraine prevention

monitoring.action: Prolonged aura needs stroke rule-out; increasing frequency reassess prevention
Escalate therapy if not meeting target; consider CGRP mAb or Botox
MOH education; consider preventive escalation; may need withdrawal
Optimize BP control given elevated vascular risk with aura
Escalate preventive therapy if severely disabled
Consider dose reduction or switch if metabolic acidosis
Add fiber/laxatives; reduce dose or discontinue if severe
**STOP IMMEDIATELY if rash develops** - SJS risk
Remove estrogen-containing contraceptives; counsel on alternatives

disposition.criteria: Typical aura pattern confirmed; no stroke symptoms; pain controlled; able to tolerate PO; follow-up arranged; contraceptive counseling if needed
Prolonged aura (>60 min) requiring observation; status migrainosus requiring IV therapy; first aura with abnormal imaging requiring further workup; hemiplegic migraine with prolonged weakness
Migrainous infarction (stroke occurring during typical aura); hemodynamic instability; severe refractory status migrainosus requiring ketamine infusion
Stroke mimicking aura requiring thrombectomy evaluation; complex hemiplegic migraine requiring tertiary headache center
New diagnosis: 2-4 weeks; Stable on prevention: 3-6 months; After preventive change: 4-8 weeks
